intro: Paullinia lingulata, commonly known as the Brazilian peppercorn, is a woody shrub or small tree native to the Atlantic rainforests of Brazil. It belongs to the Sapindaceae family and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, red, peppercorn-like fruits. The plant produces a pungent, spicy resin that has been used traditionally in various medicinal applications. Its botanical features include opposite, ovate leaves and yellowish-white flowers that bloom in clusters. The species is also notable for its ability to thrive in moist, shaded environments.
